resource_data:
<expression xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.imsglobal.org/xsd/imslorsltitm_v1p0 http://fire.eun.org/lode/imslorsltitm_v1p0.xsd" xmlns="http://www.imsglobal.org/xsd/imslorsltitm_v1p0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">

    <catalog>hdl</catalog>
    <entry>10494/107110</entry>
  </identifier>
  <identifier>
    <catalog>expression-cmr-id</catalog>

  </identifier>
  <description>
    <facet>
      <vocabularyID>LRE.expressionDescriptionFacetValues</vocabularyID>
      <value>main</value>
    </facet>
    <metadata>
      <schema>http://ltsc.ieee.org/xsd/LOM</schema>
      <lom xsi:schemaLocation="http://ltsc.ieee.org/xsd/LOM http://ltsc.ieee.org/xsd/lomv1.0/lomLoose.xsd" xmlns="http://ltsc.ieee.org/xsd/LOM">
        <general>
          <identifier>
            <catalog>oercommons.org</catalog>
            <entry>1770202792</entry>
          </identifier>
          <title>
            <string language="en">Measuring Pots (Archaeology)</string>
            <string language="x-mt-de">Messende Töpfe (Archäologie)</string>
            <string language="x-mt-fr">Pots de Mesure (Archéologie)</string>
            <string language="x-mt-pt">Potenciômetros De Medição (Archaeology)</string>
            <string language="x-mt-it">POT Di Misurazione (Archaeology)</string>
            <string language="x-mt-el">Μέτρηση των δοχείων (αρχαιολογία)</string>
            <string language="x-mt-es">Crisoles Que miden (Archaeology)</string>
          </title>
          <description>
            <string language="en">Because ancient pots are usually found broken into hundreds of pieces (sherds), archaeologists find it tedious and often impossible to glue them back together. One way they get an idea of how large a pot was is by calculating its original circumference. Rim sherds are used to do this because they often indicate how large the vessel opening was.</string>
          </description>
          <keyword>
            <string language="en">Social Sciences</string>
          </keyword>
          <language>en</language>
          <description>
            <string language="x-mt-de">Weil alten Töpfen normalerweise gebrochen in 
Hunderte Stücke (sherds) gefunden werden, finden Archäologen es 
langwierig und häufig unmöglich, sie zurück zu kleben zusammen. 
One-way erhalten sie eine Idee von, wie groß ein Topf ist war, 
indem er seinen ursprünglichen Umkreis errechnete. Kante sherds
werden verwendet, um dies zu tun, weil sie häufig anzeigen, wie groß
die Behälteröffnung war.</string>
          </description>
          <description>
            <string language="x-mt-fr">Puisque des pots antiques sont habituellement 
trouvés cassés en centaines de morceaux (sherds), les archéologues 
le trouvent pénible et souvent impossible de les coller en arrière 
ensemble. One-way ils ont une idée de la façon dont grand un 
pot était est en calculant son circonférence initiale. Des 
sherds de RIM sont employés pour faire ceci parce qu'ils indiquent 
souvent comment grand l'ouverture de navire était.</string>
          </description>
          <description>
            <string language="x-mt-pt">Porque os potenciômetros antigos são encontrados
geralmente quebrados em centenas das partes (sherds), os arqueólogos 
encontram tedious e frequentemente impossível colá-las para trás 
junto. One-way começam uma idéia de como grande um 
potenciômetro era é calculando sua circunferência original. 
Os sherds da borda são usados fazer este porque indicam 
frequentemente como grande a abertura da embarcação era.</string>
          </description>
          <description>
            <string language="x-mt-it">Poiché i POT antichi solitamente sono trovati 
tagliati nelle centinaia delle parti (sherds), gli archeologhi lo 
trovano noioso e spesso impossible incollarle indietro insieme. 
One-way ottengono un'idea di quanto grande un POT era è 
calcolando la relativa circonferenza originale. Gli sherds 
dell'orlo sono usati per fare questo perché indicano spesso quanto 
grande l'apertura del vaso era.</string>
          </description>
          <description>
            <string language="x-mt-el">Επειδή τα αρχαία δοχεία βρίσκονται συνήθως σπασμένα 
στις εκατοντάδες των κομματιών (sherds), οι αρχαιολόγοι το 
βρίσκουν κουραστικό και συχνά αδύνατο να τους κολλήσουν πίσω 
από κοινού. Ένας τρόπος παίρνουν μια ιδέα για το πόσο 
μεγάλο ένα δοχείο ήταν είναι με τον υπολογισμό της αρχικής 
περιφέρειάς του. Τα sherds πλαισίων χρησιμοποιούνται για 
να κάνουν αυτό επειδή δείχνουν συχνά πόσο μεγάλο το άνοιγμα 
σκαφών ήταν.</string>
          </description>
          <description>
            <string language="x-mt-es">Porque los crisoles antiguos generalmente se 
encuentran rotos en centenares de los pedazos (sherds), los 
arqueólogos encuentran aburrido y a menudo imposible pegarlos detrás
junto. Una forma consiguen una idea de cómo es grande era un 
crisol está calculando su circunferencia original. Los sherds 
del borde se utilizan para hacer esto porque indican a menudo cómo es
grande era la apertura del recipiente.</string>
          </description>
          <keyword>
            <string language="x-mt-de">Sozialwissenschaften</string>
          </keyword>
          <keyword>
            <string language="x-mt-fr">Les Sciences Sociales</string>
          </keyword>
          <keyword>
            <string language="x-mt-pt">Ciências Sociais</string>
          </keyword>
          <keyword>
            <string language="x-mt-it">Scienze Sociali</string>
          </keyword>
          <keyword>
            <string language="x-mt-el">Κοινωνικές επιστήμες</string>
          </keyword>
          <keyword>
            <string language="x-mt-es">Ciencias Sociales</string>
          </keyword>
        </general>
        <lifeCycle>
          <contribute>
            <role>
              <source>roleValues</source>
              <value>author</value>
            </role>
            <entity>BEGIN:VCARD

          </contribute>
        </lifeCycle>

      </lom>
    </metadata>
  </description>
